You might be thinking, "Yeah, you just don't understand the icons." Wrong. I played it enough times to learn the icons. My beef with this game is as follows:

This game is no "race." It has nothing to do with space. Like most Eurogames' it has nothing to with anything.

Want to save money and get the gist of this game? Call 3 friends over. Give each person a set of playing cards. Play solitaire. Whoever gets the most cards played at the top wins. That's it. I just saved you about $30 (USD). You're welcome.

You know what chaps my @ss about this game? I have a powerful military (also known as "red" cards). I'm the friggin' galactic Empire loaded to the hilt with Star Destroyers and led by Darth Vadar himself! You are a bunch of peace loving hippie beatnecks. I come over and demand that you pay tribute (in other words, extortion) and if not, then I will conquer some of your planets filled with long haired weirdos.

The problem is I can't. Why not? I have lasers! I have disruptors, photon torpedoes. You have Joan Baez singing "How many roads must a man go down?" I'm about to implement some Pax Instersellerica on you, but I can't do it. Why not? Because the rules say I can't interact with you!

Why is that? The only rational explanation is that we are too far apart, like on the opposite sides of the galaxy or something. Huh? Then how are we able to play off of the same roles? How do you know who won the "race?" How did you even agree on the terms of what the race was? I bet I can get to the end of my town before you can get to the end of yours. By the way, I'm in Kansas and you in France. Ready? Set? Go!

See, that's the problem with Eurogames: there is nothing rooted in reality. It's just a multi-player solitaire puzzle masquerading as a group game.

Defenders of this corpse are quick to point out to me that if I go buy a bunch of expansions, THEN, I actually get to, you know ... interact with you. My answer?

*Mic Drop*

It's an acknowledgement that you have to spend a bunch of money just to make it not suck as much.

So if you are a sad Eurogamer who can't break free, I'll help you out. If you want a game using these mechanics that is a LOT more fun go play San Juan. The game immerses players in a rich sci-fi universe where various factions compete to dominate the galaxy through technological advancements, economic development, and military might.

Mechanisms:
```
Utilizes a unique iconography system to manage resources, world developments, and actions.

Players select roles each turn that determine what actions all players can perform, promoting strategic foresight and planning.

This role selection combined with a hand management mechanic drives the game's depth and replayability.
```

It turns out I had not been missing out.

The main culprit here is clearly the constant random draw from a moderately large card pool to individual hands. On top of forcing things to be overy tactical on your side, it makes opponents equally hard to predict and removes any layer of indirect interaction that other similar VP engine games like Dominion (with its central common market of cards) would have. Besides, even if I could picture a level of expertise where it would be possible to start accounting for the action phases opponents are likely to select, and even if the requirement of basically internalising everyone else's complicated tableau on top of mine didn’t sound like stabbing my eyeball with a wooden spoon, the amount of 100% pure multiplayer solitaire sessions necessary for me to develop that skill would not be worth it, when I’d probably still deem the result a mockery of multiplayer.

There are elements of similarity to a 3x space game and the way the cards show up (explore), how they are played out (expand) and how you use them (exploit). Otherwise it's something similar to the usual dry tableau/engine-building games as well as combinatorial card games in MtG's legacy. It's quiet and non-interactive race for victory points that is played in a heads-down fashion; one is chaining symbols, building combos and exploiting synergies. It seems like it's a purer destillation than most, also in the context of later releases.

However, in the best case scenario you take the opponent's tableau into account when choosing your action, but you need more or less precise knowledge of the card pool and possible sequence combinations, which requires dozens to hundreds of games. Kurzrezension:
Ein "Race for the Galaxy" ist gestartet, bei dem jeder Spieler möglichst schnell die Galaxie bevölkern, um damit Ruhm zu erlangen. Um dieses Ziel zu erreichen, müssen Planeten besiedelt oder erobert sowie neue Technologien erforscht und zur Anwendung gebracht werden.

Spielablauf:
Die Spieler starten mit einer kleinen Hand voll Karten. Diese dienen im Spiel neben ihren Eigenschaften nach dem Ausspielen als Zahlungsmittel.
Das Spiel ist in fünf Phasen aufgeteilt. Welche davon gespielt werden, wird von den Spielern selbst bestimmt, indem sie zu Beginn jeder Runde eine Phasenkarte wählen und jeder seine dann gemeinsam aufdeckt.
In Phase '1', der 'Erforschung' erhalten die Spieler neue Handkarten vom gemeinsamen Nachzugstapel. In Phase '2' der 'Entwicklung' dürfen die Spieler Entwicklungskarten ausspielen und müssen diese mit ihren restlichen Handkarten bezahlen, indem sie diese abwerfen. Beim 'Besiedeln' in Phase '3' verhält es sich ähnlich, nur dass Planetensysteme ausgespielt werden, auf denen Güter hergestellt werden können. Militärische Welten benötigen obendrein genügend Stärke, um ausgespielt zu werden. Phase '4' kümmert sich dann um den Verbrauch von Gütern, die auf den Planetensystemen liegen und sorgen so für Punkte oder neue Handkarten. Um an diese Güter zu kommen, ist die 'Produktion' in Phase '5' zuständig, womit alles erklärt ist.
Diejenigen Spieler, die eine Phase ausgewählt haben, erhalten in dieser eine etwas stärkere Fähigkeit als die anderen Spieler, aber alle gewählten Phasen werden dennoch von allen Spielern genutzt. Phasen, die nicht gewählt wurden, werden in der Runde einfach übersprungen.
Sobald ein Spieler 12 Entwicklungs- und/oder Planeten vor sich ausliegen hat oder der Vorrat an Siegpunktechips zur Neige geht, endet das Spiel und derjenige mit den meisten Punkten gewinnt.

Meinung:
"Race for the Galaxy" ist bereits einige Jahre alt, hat aber keinesfalls an Charme verloren. Besonders clever ist natürlich die Mechanik, die Handkarten sowohl als auszuspielende Karten, als auch als Zahlungsmittel zu verwenden. Das sorgt dafür, dass sich die Spieler immer wieder von Karten trennen müssen, die sie eigentlich ausgespielt vor sich liegen sehen wollten. Ein toller Konflikt.
Die Symbolsprache ist das, worüber viele Spieler bei "Race for the Galaxy" stolpern. Sobald sie einmal verstanden ist, kann sie aber gut nachvollzogen werden. Zu Beginn versteht sie aber wirklich niemand. 
Ich finde "Race for the Galaxy" ein sehr gutes Spiel, das über die Jahre nur sehr wenig Spielreiz verloren hat. Leider kommt es dennoch nicht sehr häufig auf den Spieltisch, was definitiv geändert werden muss.

Pros:
It's my favourite game, and I suspect it always will be. It's just so packed with interesting decisions in such a short playtime with plenty of variety and interaction while not feeling mean or random. It's unique, absolutely brilliant and maybe one of very few perfect games. The cards as currency is a great conceit and makes the whole game feel very smart and streamlined.

The ratio of interesting decision-making to playtime is the highest of any game I've ever played, which makes it such a force to be reckoned with. Why play Terraforming Mars or Wingspan when I could play this in an eighth of the time and make more interesting decisions?

It has simple but deep tableau building with cards with multiple, interesting effects. I love that not only does each card have different uses as both a currency or its printed effect, but the printed effects can fit into your engine in a multitude of different ways because of how much utility is packed into a single card. Maybe you care about the color of goods it produces, maybe it allows you to leech off of a phase your opponent will call often or maybe it's just worth the most points and you know you'll fill your hand later in the round.

I think it's one of the most interactive games I've played where you can only affect each other in a positive way. The phase system works really well and is one of my favorite mechanisms in any game. The bluffing and double-thinking is such a subtle but strong interaction point that newer players don't realize even exists, but is a big part of why experience players will almost always crush a newer player. If you can play around what your opponent(s) have played, you have a huge advantage and it's all about reading your opponent(s) and understanding their intentions based on their open board state.

The game scales excellently. The 2PA variant is my favourite version and the most strategic, but I like all player counts and I appreciate that they all feel differently. Sure 6 players is pretty chaotic, but it's still a fun game that just has a bit more of a lighthearted feel.

Cons:
A lot of people complain about iconography, but I think that's more of a meme than actual fact. It's a bit hard to teach, but I think that's more because the decision space is so large. Your tableau can become quite complex quite quickly and the iconography is in fact the only reason this works so well, with poorer iconography the game would be unplayable. The fact that you have 2 hands and both need to be hidden at all times also makes the game hard to teach, since many players don't want to ask about hidden information. The game is best after you've played it more than a dozen times and that is a hard sell these days, but it's just so worth it.

If you introduce the game to someone that hasn't been on BGG and heard the decries of the "iconography hell" they won't have any trouble learning the 8 or so icons of the base game with the help of the excellent player aid. This isn't some argument I'm pulling out of a hat either, I've taught this game to dozens of relatively novice gamers and iconography was never where they stumbled.

Most instead stumbled getting an economy going and exhaust their resources and end up exploring throughout the mid-game. I can totally understand complaints relating to the difficulty of learning to play well, but that's not related to the iconography.

I think a lot of people complaining about iconography are influenced by e.g. the SU&SD review of RftG, where they, perhaps unintentionally, showed a bunch of admittedly very intimidating icons that were all from expansions. I found most of those difficult to learn as well, but I expect a higher learning curve from the third expansion so the point is moot.

It's a card game so there's some randomness, but it's rare for draws to decide a game. Yes, you can get a god-draw that ends a game quickly without the other players having a chance, but even such a rare occurrence isn't much of an issue for such a fast game. The extremely large amount of cards you see compared to how many you play in a single game and the fact that cards have multiple effects and uses means that luck of the draw is rarely a game-deciding factor.

An actual problem I have with this game is that the setup is a bit too long and cumbersome compared to the play time, especially the part about shuffling in the start worlds. Other games in this series, like Roll for the Galaxy and New Frontiers have separate start worlds that don't get shuffled and that would have been a nice change in the second edition. I may try to print extra copies of the start worlds, but it's not a very elegant solution.
There have been times when I have increased my rating for RftG after playing a non-RftG card game. It's just in a class of its own.
